Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I woke up to a string of messages from my mom, each one more insistent than the last: “Good morning! How are you feeling today?” “Did you eat breakfast?” “Don’t forget to tell me about your plans!” I know she worries if I don’t reply quickly, and I’ve always made it a point to keep her updated, especially since I moved out. But today, my mind is racing for a different reason. I realized I left my ID at home, and with the election tomorrow, this morning is my only window to pick it up before work. The polling station is strict—no ID, no vote. My phone buzzes again, and I feel the familiar tug of guilt. If I don’t answer, my mom will worry all day. If I stop to text her, I might miss my train and lose my only chance to vote. I stand in the hallway, phone in hand, torn between the comfort of my mother’s expectations and the responsibility of my civic duty, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
